Waratah Terraces (see note) is still there (minus one at right) and surrounded by later buildings. Google Street View maps.google.com/maps?hl=en&ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=...

One chap has come up with dates and histories.

There is also supposedly a similar shot in Newcastle University Cultural Collections, but am unable to catch the link.

comment.author: 51487922@N05
comment._content: All these links take you to the UON Cultural collections with different dates for various scenes of Newcastle, except the first, which is the link to the Hunter Valley Rootsweb list, browse through the archives. lists.rootsweb.ancestry.com/index/intl/AUS/AUS-NSW-Hunter... flic.kr/p/8pC7AD View from the Obelisk], Newcastle, NSW, [1906] flic.kr/p/8pC7L2 View from the obelisk], Newcastle, NSW, [1906] flic.kr/p/8pC7FH [View from the obelisk], Newcastle, NSW, [1906] flic.kr/p/7yAZux Newcastle coast line from Shepherds Hill looking north, Newcastle, NSW, [1891] flic.kr/p/6wVooo Tents at Fort Scratchley, Newcastle, NSW, 11 April 1903 flic.kr/p/6wRdnt Newcastle Beach, Newcastle, 5 November 1898] flic.kr/p/6wRc4k Newcastle Beach [25 October 1909] flic.kr/p/6wVmQS View of Newcastle from Fort Scratchley, Newcastle, NSW, [n.d.] While on the UON site there were also the building of Christ Church, but I closed them down before grabbing the links. www.flickr.com/photos/uon/sets/72157608912691810/ Ralph Snowball was a stickler for recording his dates and where, but there have been some that were not quite right.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Perhaps this photo is early enough to be the Colonial Architects Office record of the building of Fort Scratchley in c.1882 ?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Or: Pre- Fort Scratchley, c.1880? The warehouse under construction (see note) is also in the same state in John Rae's panorama of Newcastle (about 1875-80) made as a comparison to his 1849 sketch. See page 5 of www.newcastle.edu.au/Resources/Divisions/Academic/Library... . This panorama was taken from further right and higher, possibly the Obelisk mentioned above. I wonder if this photo was part of another panorama taken by John Rae at the same time? Hence the odd composition with roofs in the foreground.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Oh my, wouldn't it be funny to discover once again part of a Rae panorama in SRNSW collection - www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4865044772/ - Whether or not it is indeed Rae, I share your suspicion it is likely to be part of a panorama.

comment.author: 51487922@N05
comment._content:
Source: Newcastle Sketchbook, drawings by Lionel Long, text by Brian Davies, first published 1980, ISBN 0727008889

Page 8
Fort Scratchley was completed in 1886

LMDHS

comment.author: 51487922@N05
comment._content:
Source: Newcastle and Hunter Valley Sketchbook, drawings by Unk White, text by Alan Farrelly, first published 1969, National Library of Australia Registry Number AUS68-877

Page 52
A local committee built a new hospital in 1866

The article doesn't mention when additions were made.

Incidentally
X-rays in 1896, operated by the hospital's electrician who was the first in Australia to demonstrate this new form of photography a few weeks after news of Roentgen's discovery.

The electrician was Walter Drowley Filmer whose residence was on the shores of Lake Macquarie at Toronto.

LMDHS

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Fort Scratchley - Guns in position 4 April 1882 barrack completed (in 11 months) 1886 - not evident in this photo dry moat and wall 1892 - not there from - www.fortscratchley.com.au/history/highlights and www.fortscratchley.org/ Hospital - see www.flickr.com/photos/uon/3744591820/ at Original size (amazing) Left side 1865, right side 1884 (NB those would be building dates, not opening) The corner stone of the New Wing was laid on Thursday 25/9/1884 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/18937179 . No building work is evident in the photo.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [ A fascinating red herring - 50 Scott St, the Waratah Terrace name house, is for sale. Have a sticky beak! - www.bqnre.com.au/main.php?page=property&pid=1528 . btw their "c.1892" is way off. ]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Old Newcastle Gaol demolished in early 1876 - MM&HRGA 19/2/1876 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/18803536 " That relic of the early population of the City of Newcastle, viz., the Old Gaol, is being rapidly removed from the surface of the earth, and before many days it will be actually, as it has long been nominally, a thing of the past. The crumbling walls are now being pulled down, and the rubbish removed in carts. At the present the.'institution" shows to the town a long array of cells, which have been opened up to view by the pulling away of the front wall. What tales could they not unfold were they gifted with speech. "

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Thanks to Trove I found an advert for the sale in “Scott-street” of a “terrace of nine commodious and convenient houses, adjacent to the Customs House.” Probably the same terrace as was put to tender a year earlier, mentioned by Jenny in the blog discussion. But is Waratah Terrace adjacent to the Customs House, or two blocks away? See MM&HRGA 19/10/1882 p.1 – trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/860215 So we have a date range of 1882 [?] – 1884 so far, imho.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: E U R E K A ! The presence of the Newcastle Sailors Home (see note LH side), even though a tiny part, means that this photo is late 1882 at the EARLIEST. The building's Foundation Stone was laid on 17/3/1882: completed on 18/12/1882 and handed over to the Committee on 24/2/1883. See full history here - www.heritage.nsw.gov.au/07_subnav_02_2.cfm?itemid=5054876 . More importantly, the Sailors Home also shows up on the John Rae photographic Panorama, proving that it is also late 1882 at the EARLIEST (as previously thought). An online hi-res version - coalriver.files.wordpress.com/2008/09/rae1878.jpg (from coalriver.wordpress.com/2008/09/02/invitation-to-newcastl... ).

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: John Rae exhibited his Panoramas at the Calcutta International Exhibition in 1883-4. Dovetails ! Incidentally I think the Rae photo panorama was taken from the tower of Jesmond House (NW corner of Barker and Ordnance Streets). [http://www.flickr.com/photos/uon/3723106708/] And to complete the "where", over on the blog 'Jenny' identified that Claremont House balcony, Newcomen Street (in front of the Cathedral) was where John Rae painted his 1847 panorama using a camera obscura. Also where this photo was taken from. Google Street view - maps.google.com/maps?hl=en&ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=...

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Watching the unfolding of this Moment in Time has been amazing and we are impressed! Everyone deserves chocolates but I think you'd all agree that [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] would get first pick (puns aside...although we really did get a laugh out of it). Honourable mentions to Jenny and Debbie (and ahem Wally) over on Archives Outside and the Hunter Valley Rootsweb list and [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51487922@N05] here on Flickr. It started as an "unidentified and undated coastal residential landscape" and was discovered to be a view over Newcastle looking towards Flagstaff Hill and Newcastle Beach and narrowed down to late 1882-1884. A fantastic group effort! As [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] says: B R I L L I A N T I S S I M O ! AB

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] [munching on the NuTtY choccies] Thanks all - that was fun.  I now know more about Newcastle East in the early 1880s than is proper.

Still trying to prove the photo is part of a John Rae panorama;  the evidence so far is good, but  circumstantial.  If anybody knows anything useful please add it.
